prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for deleting his ex’ contact number in his phone?
Bf and I allow full access to each other’s phones.  I saw his ex in his contacts and asked him why she was still in there.   He said he just hadn’t bothered to remove her yet, but had no intention of contacting her again.  So I deleted her.   He was surprised and asked me why I did that.  I just said if you’re not going to contact her why have her in there.   I can tell he’s bothered, but am I wrong?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong for deleting their partner's ex's contact number from his phone. The setup is that the couple allows full phone access. The boyfriend had an ex in his contacts, said he didn't plan to contact her, and the author deleted her. The BF got surprised and seems bothered. The question is whether the author is in the wrong.

Hmm. So, first, the couple has an open agreement about phone access. The author saw the ex in the contacts and asked, which is reasonable. The BF said he wasn't going to contact her but hadn't deleted her yet. The author then took the step to delete her. The BF is now upset.

I need to consider both sides. On one hand, the author acted on their own without asking, even if the BF said he'd delete her. Maybe the BF felt his autonomy was invaded. Even if the BF didn't plan to contact her, having her in contacts might be personal. On the other hand, the author might have thought they were helping, removing a reminder of the ex. The BF's reaction shows he was bothered, which could indicate that the action was unwanted. 

Also, communication is key. The author could have discussed it more, given the BF time to delete her himself. Taking action without permission, even if allowed access, might overstep. Privacy and autonomy matter. Even if the BF didn't mind sharing phones, personal contacts might be a sensitive area. So, maybe the author was wrong to delete without further discussion. The answer would be A (yes, in the wrong).
